clinical_study.official_title: Pilot Study to Determine the Effect of Different Dialyzer Membranes on Clotting During Haemodiafiltration Treatments in Patients With Chronic Kidney Disease

brief_summary.textblock:
Primary Objective:
The purpose of this study is to measure the amount of convection achieved with two different haemodiafilters designed for haemodiafiltration and clotting during haemodiafiltration treatment.

detailed_description.textblock: This is a prospective observational cohort pilot study of patients under the care of the Royal Free Hospital with chronic kidney disease who have been established on regular thrice weekly haemodiafiltration treatments in a dialysis centre. Information on the study will be disseminated to the Royal Free consultant nephrologists at the dialysis centre with primary responsibility for the individual patient.

primary_outcome.description: volume of convective exchange achieved during the HDF session

secondary_outcome.description: measurement of coagulation pathway proteins and platelet activation markers
visual analogue score assessment of clotting in the extracorporeal circuit

secondary_outcome.measure: small and middle sized solute clearances
secondary_outcome.description: dialyzer clearance of small and middle sized molecules, including urea and beta 2 microglobulin

arm_group.description: single haemodiafiltration treatment using a SOLACEA 21H dialyzer (Nipro Corp, Osaka, Japan)
single haemodiafiltration treatment using a FX100 dialyzer (Fresenius MC, Bad Homburg, Germany)

study_pop.textblock: attending RFH kidney care centre for routine outpatient HDF treatments for chronic kidney disease

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients age 18 years and older up to 80 years
- Under the care of the Royal Free Hospital with chronic kidney disease and established on regular thrice weekly haemodiafiltration.
- Able to provide written informed consent obtained
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients scheduled for a kidney transplant
- Patients taking concomitant systemic anticoagulants
- Patients with known prothrombotic or bleeding disorders
- Patients with abnormal platelet counts
- Patients unable to provide written informed consent
- Patients not fulfilling inclusion criteria
